guide.introduction:
Most DIY copper etching techniques require the use of some etching compound. While not all are as nasty as ferric chloride, the etchants are still consumable and require the disposal of solutions containing copper ions, toxic to marine life.

With galvanic etching, a potential difference is doing the work of removing copper, and it is plated out on the cathode as fast as it is removed from the anode. That means that once made, the solution can be used indefinitely, and you don't need to buy more hydrogen peroxide or hydrochloric acid.

This setup could also be used for copper plating or with other metals with slight modifications
guide.introduction_rendered:
Most DIY copper etching techniques require the use of some etching compound. While not all are as nasty as ferric chloride, the etchants are still consumable and require the disposal of solutions containing copper ions, toxic to marine life.

With galvanic etching, a potential difference is doing the work of removing copper, and it is plated out on the cathode as fast as it is removed from the anode. That means that once made, the solution can be used indefinitely, and you don't need to buy more hydrogen peroxide or hydrochloric acid.

This setup could also be used for copper plating or with other metals with slight modifications

Relevant parts
  • Circuit board with resist
  • Spacers
  • Copper wire
  • Electrical Tape
Tools
  • Adjustable power supply
  • Airtight containter
  • Flat copper sheet or copper clad board
  • Tray, dish, or pan
  • Vinegar

parts.notes: Guides are available for methods such as toner transfer, photoresist, hand-drawn, and other methods.
Pieces of insulated wire work well

lines.text: Cut two pieces of bare copper wire for electrodes. The length isn't crucial, but should be at least a few centimeters.
lines.text_raw: Cut two pieces of bare copper wire for electrodes. The length isn't crucial, but should be at least a few centimeters.

lines.text: Bend the wires, if needed, place them in the tray, and tape them. The goal is to have most of them eventually submerged, but enough exposed to clip leads to. They should be close, but never touching.
lines.text_raw: Bend the wires, if needed, place them in the tray, and tape them. The goal is to have most of them eventually submerged, but enough exposed to clip leads to. They should be close, but never touching.

lines.text: Fill the tray with vinegar to a depth of at least 1 centimeter.
lines.text_raw: Fill the tray with vinegar to a depth of at least 1 centimeter.

lines.text: Starting with the power supply at 0V, hook up one copper electrode to the positive of your power supply and one to the negative.
lines.text_raw: Starting with the power supply at 0V, hook up one copper electrode to the positive of your power supply and one to the negative.

lines.text: Increase the voltage to 1 - 1.5 V. The current should be ~xxx mA.
lines.text_raw: Increase the voltage to 1 - 1.5 V. The current should be ~xxx mA.

lines.text: Wait. Bubbles should be produces at the cathode, and the solution should begin to take on a blue color.
lines.text_raw: Wait. Bubbles should be produces at the cathode, and the solution should begin to take on a blue color.

lines.text: When bubbling is no longer perceptible and the solution is a rich blue, the solution is ready.
lines.text_raw: When bubbling is no longer perceptible and the solution is a rich blue, the solution is ready.

lines.text: The electrodes will need to be set up for etching flat boards. To do this, take a flat piece of copper or a second piece of copper clad board of the same or larger size and make sure it fits in the bottom of your dish.
lines.text_raw: The electrodes will need to be set up for etching flat boards. To do this, take a flat piece of copper or a second piece of copper clad board of the same or larger size and make sure it fits in the bottom of your dish.

lines.text: Attach a piece of copper wire to it. You want a good electrical connection. Drilling a hole and looping wire through it is good, or you can simply bend wire around a corner and squash it with pliers.
lines.text_raw: Attach a piece of copper wire to it. You want a good electrical connection. Drilling a hole and looping wire through it is good, or you can simply bend wire around a corner and squash it with pliers.

lines.text: Cut four 2 centimeter pieces of insulated wire and bend them into L shapes.
lines.text_raw: Cut four 2 centimeter pieces of insulated wire and bend them into L shapes.

lines.text: Attach a piece of copper wire to the board ready to be etched. If there are going to be holes for standoffs, you could drill one out and loop wire through that. If not, just try to crimp wire onto any patch of bare copper at the edge.
lines.text_raw: Attach a piece of copper wire to the board ready to be etched. If there are going to be holes for standoffs, you could drill one out and loop wire through that. If not, just try to crimp wire onto any patch of bare copper at the edge.

lines.text: Place the flat electrode into the bottom of the tray with the solution in it.
lines.text_raw: Place the flat electrode into the bottom of the tray with the solution in it.

lines.text: Place the L shaped wires onto this electrode so they can support the circuit board.
lines.text_raw: Place the L shaped wires onto this electrode so they can support the circuit board.

lines.text: Place the circuit board with resist onto the insulated wire spacers. If it floats or slides, weigh it down slightly.
lines.text_raw: Place the circuit board with resist onto the insulated wire spacers. If it floats or slides, weigh it down slightly.

lines.text: At this point, you should have two copper surfaces separated by a small gap, the width of the wires with insulation. Make sure the wires are not touching.
lines.text_raw: At this point, you should have two copper surfaces separated by a small gap, the width of the wires with insulation. Make sure the wires are not touching.

lines.text: Hook the circuit board to the positive terminal of the power supply and hook the bottom electrode to the negative terminal.
lines.text_raw: Hook the circuit board to the positive terminal of the power supply and hook the bottom electrode to the negative terminal.

lines.text: Ideal etching voltage, current, and time vary somewhat. Things to consider:
lines.text_raw: Ideal etching voltage, current, and time vary somewhat. Things to consider:

lines.text: The rate of copper removal is proportional to the current. Higher currents thus mean shorter etching times.
lines.text_raw: The rate of copper removal is proportional to the current. Higher currents thus mean shorter etching times.

lines.text: Some resists are more robust than others. Toner transfer boards may need to be run at lower currents if you have trouble with resist flaking off.
lines.text_raw: Some resists are more robust than others. Toner transfer boards may need to be run at lower currents if you have trouble with resist flaking off.

lines.text: To increase the current, you need to increase the voltage. If you go too high, however, you get competing reactions such as water splitting, which wastes energy and makes resist-damaging bubbles. To be on the safe side, stay below 1.2 V. Higher voltages may work, but you may get issues with resist flaking off.
lines.text_raw: To increase the current, you need to increase the voltage. If you go too high, however, you get competing reactions such as water splitting, which wastes energy and makes resist-damaging bubbles. To be on the safe side, stay below 1.2 V. Higher voltages may work, but you may get issues with resist flaking off.

lines.text: If you are at 1.2 V but still want higher current, you can try reducing the electrode gap by using thinner standoff wires.
lines.text_raw: If you are at 1.2 V but still want higher current, you can try reducing the electrode gap by using thinner standoff wires.

lines.text: Your specific details will vary by setup, but for a spacing of about XXX mm, 1 V will give a current of approximately xxx mA. Theoretically, this should etch 1 cm of 1 ounce board in xxx minutes.
lines.text_raw: Your specific details will vary by setup, but for a spacing of about XXX mm, 1 V will give a current of approximately xxx mA. Theoretically, this should etch 1 cm of 1 ounce board in xxx minutes.

lines.text: Let it etch, checking occasionally. When done, the board may have faint copper coloration between the lines, but should have no measurable conductivity.
lines.text_raw: Let it etch, checking occasionally. When done, the board may have faint copper coloration between the lines, but should have no measurable conductivity.

lines.text: At this point, disconnect the power, gently shake off the circuit board, and rinse it. You now have your etched circuit board.
lines.text_raw: At this point, disconnect the power, gently shake off the circuit board, and rinse it. You now have your etched circuit board.

lines.text: If you want to do more, everything is perfectly set up. Otherwise, pour the solution into a storage container. No matter how pretty the color is, make sure it is labelled so people won't drink it.
lines.text_raw: If you want to do more, everything is perfectly set up. Otherwise, pour the solution into a storage container. No matter how pretty the color is, make sure it is labelled so people won't drink it.

lines.text: You can rinse your electrode and dish off and store them for future use.
lines.text_raw: You can rinse your electrode and dish off and store them for future use.

lines.text: The next time you want to etch a circuit, simply pour the solution into your tray, put in the bottom electrode, away you go. The only thing consumed each time is electricity.
lines.text_raw: The next time you want to etch a circuit, simply pour the solution into your tray, put in the bottom electrode, away you go. The only thing consumed each time is electricity.

lines.text: If you are wondering what happens to the copper, it ends up plated out on the bottom electrode. Depending on how fast you are etching, it may grow on the electrode, form a sheet on top of it, or just form a powder. When the buildup becomes thick, you may want to remove it so the electrode is an even height. After rinsing, this copper can go in your scrap jar.
lines.text_raw: If you are wondering what happens to the copper, it ends up plated out on the bottom electrode. Depending on how fast you are etching, it may grow on the electrode, form a sheet on top of it, or just form a powder. When the buildup becomes thick, you may want to remove it so the electrode is an even height. After rinsing, this copper can go in your scrap jar.

lines.text: If you loose to much solution between pouring back and forth between storage and use, you can add vinegar or water. Vinegar will temporarily cause some bubbling during etching, like during the original step. Water doesn't do this, but will reduce the current for a given voltage.
lines.text_raw: If you loose to much solution between pouring back and forth between storage and use, you can add vinegar or water. Vinegar will temporarily cause some bubbling during etching, like during the original step. Water doesn't do this, but will reduce the current for a given voltage.

lines.text: For maximum awesomeness, you should just reuse the same solution. You may, however, you decide you won't be making any more circuit boards and want to dispose of your solution. The solution is safer than used ferric chloride and probably about the same as used hydrogen peroxide/muriatic acid. You have a few options:
lines.text_raw: For maximum awesomeness, you should just reuse the same solution. You may, however, you decide you won't be making any more circuit boards and want to dispose of your solution. The solution is safer than used ferric chloride and probably about the same as used hydrogen peroxide/muriatic acid. You have a few options:

lines.text: Hypothetically, someone could dilute it and pour it down the drain. This would be less damaging than someone who was dumping used solutions every time they made a board. Copper ions are poisonous for marine life and in higher concentrations for humans, though.
lines.text_raw: Hypothetically, someone ''could'' dilute it and pour it down the drain. This would be less damaging than someone who was dumping used solutions every time they made a board. Copper ions are poisonous for marine life and in higher concentrations for humans, though.

lines.text: Hypothetically, someone could also let the solution evaporate and throw the resulting blue crystals in a landfill.
lines.text_raw: Hypothetically, someone could also let the solution evaporate and throw the resulting blue crystals in a landfill.

lines.text: Adding sodium bicarbonate (baking soda) to the solution will result in a precipitate of copper carbonate. If you take this solid and heat it enough, you get copper oxide, which is pretty harmless.
lines.text_raw: Adding sodium bicarbonate (baking soda) to the solution will result in a precipitate of copper carbonate. If you take this solid and heat it enough, you get copper oxide, which is pretty harmless.

lines.text: If you want to make sure you take it entirely back to the starting point, or if you just want to try smelting, heating copper carbonate or copper oxide with crushed charcoal will make metallic copper.
lines.text_raw: If you want to make sure you take it entirely back to the starting point, or if you just want to try smelting, heating copper carbonate or copper oxide with crushed charcoal will make metallic copper.
